div1.p: Carter understands that the African section of the manuscript, which was written by Henry Rose Carter during his failing health, requires considerable editing.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, July 29, 1930
div1.opener:
Book Misel, Frost, W. H.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
July 29, 1930.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
Your letter of July 27th., re the African Section of Father's MS.
has just reached me.

I am not surprised and I do not expect to be even “a bit shocked”
at the drastic editing you have found necessary.

Your inference that this last Section was written under very dif-
ferent conditions from the rest of the MS. is correct. Father began
having more frequent, and more severe, attacks of angina some months
after his return from the trip to Jamaica; the first soon after the con-
ference with Russell, Beeuwkes, Noguchi and White relative to the contem-
plated work in West Africa. I do not believe, however, that the conference
was a factor in the marked decline of his health at this time. From then on,
however, his work was done under extreme physical difficulties. You are
correct also about the feeling of “stress and hurry” about the African Sec-
tion, (in such marked contrast to the former part of the work.) Father
wanted to get to “historic yellow fever” in Africa, as he had done for the
Americas. aAfter, whichthis he intended to do no more new work until he had very
carefully edited that already done. Including the African Section, this
would have been a complete entity and, as he told me: “A good stopping
place, if I have to.” As you know, however, this final editing had only
been going on a few days before Father's last illness began. I think that
he realized that the Section on Africa would need special attention in
his final revision, although, of course he did not realize how much. The
same applies to myself. I was desperately tired, “working against time,”
with Father and nursing him during his heart attacks. I did, however, real-
ize, that the narrative should be more consecutive and that some of the
repetitions etc. should be taken out. It was mainly on this account that
when, during Father's last illness, Dr. Russell sent me a special delivery
letter, telling me that steps were being taken to immediately publish Father's
book. I replied asking him on no account to do so:---That Father were
well enough to know that the book had been published, he would be well e-
nough to know that it had been published before it was as he would have
wished it to be. It was a kind, nay, a beautiful, thought of Russell's and
I shall always be grateful to him for it.

Understand, I by no means realized, at that time, the extent of the
editing needed for the African Section. I realized it far more fully, so
far as the text was concerned, during the winter I spent in Baltimore,
when I made copiousn notes and cross-references, in note books, on the type-
writer and on the margin of Father's MS, in the expectation and hope that
they would save you work later. However, when we finally got together on
the MS I realized that your method of proceedure would be too different
from that used by Father and myself for them to be of any use to you. In-
deed, I only mention them now because they will show (if you haven't-very
properly!-disposed of them as “supercargo”) that I was even then (1926-7) much
impressed with the difficulties of the African Section.

My worst “jolt” (in connection with the African Section) however, was in the
spring of 1928, when I found (while working at the Library of Congress)
that all bibliographic references would have to be verified, even when no
verbatim quotations were involved. I wrote you of this in the summer of
of
-2-
1928. This in reply to a very considerate letter of your own, in which
you stated that you thought that Miss Brown and I were putting in too
much work in checking our references. Your experience with the other
parts of the book made your assumption almost an inevitable one and I had
begun my work (fortunately we started with the African Section) with the
same “slant” on it as yourself. own.

I feel it Providential that you (the only man capable of doing so)
should so generously have placed your great gifts at the service of your
old friend! I also feel with you that “in justice” to him the African
Section should be drastically edited. Of course you have probably seen
the need of making many changes in matters beyond me, but...I shall not
be “surprised” and I do not expect to be “shocked”...only profoundly
grateful! It is the African Section I have had specially in mind when I
have written to Dr. Russell about your turning out the book “as Father
wished it to be.”

You say that I can be of use to you if I am “still in Washington by
the end of this week.” Of course I shall be! What do you think that
I am living for? The completion of the book is the one thing left me to
look forward to. Please rest assured then that I shall be more than
thankful to do anything possible, either here or in Baltimore, that will
help you in furthering the routine part of the work. The harder part,
alas! no one can relieve you of.

With much love to Susan and looking forward to seeing you both
whenever I can be of use,

closer.seg:
P. S. I sent you, last Friday, a retyped page from Father's MS (iii, ii, 60)
re the expedition of “Boudewijn Hendricksz” (See De Laet and Southey)
in 1625. Also, as per your request, additional bibliographic cards on this
expedition from other sources. The above was sent, by registered mail,
to your office, Susan having not then told me that you were working at
home.
I also sent you (same day) a letter asking you to “lay off” Barbot
(iii, ii. 81-85) and Commercial Voyages (iii, ii. 105-108) until I sent
you retyped pages of the MS (with wide spacing and corrected refs.) and
also some additional bib. cards.
I further told you that I could let you see such vols. of Hakluyt and
Walchenaer (3 or 4 all that are necessary) as would give you additional
data on Drake, Commercial Voyages, the Portuguese Pilot etc. You probaly
have all this material by now, but repetition is better than omission. in this
case.
L. A. C.
